commit_message:
Require auth for version api call

The version call may contain information that should not be publicly
discloused without authentication. This change removes the version call
from the public urls which will cause it to require authentication
before responding with version information.

Change-Id: I7352f83ec67321a1fb5caa75fc9168cc01229083
Closes-Bug: #1585137
(cherry picked from commit 5372982b3e7221831a4bd6386e89e9b9992e73e9)
(cherry picked from commit c344c4ac6e791b9cab6e88f05ff1489b9702f38d)

commit_message:
Don't allow " " as key pair name

This patch fixes the bug where " " space character was accepted while
importing a new Key-Pair in the launch instance modal of the Horizon
Dashboard.
The regex used earlier: "^[\w\- ]+$" allowed spaces in the beginning and at
the end of the keypair which gave birth to inadmissable key-pair results.
Details on the modified variable KEYPAIR_NAME_REGEX:
^   Beginning. Matches the beginning of the string, or the
    beginning of a line if the multiline flag (m) is enabled.
\w  Word. Matches any word character (alphanumeric & underscore).
+   Plus. Match 1 or more of the preceding token.
(?: Non-capturing group. Groups multiple tokens together
    without creating a capture group.
[   Character set. Match any character in the set.
-   Character. Matches a "-" character (char code 45).
    Character. Matches a SPACE character (char code 32).
]
\w  Word. Matches any word character (alphanumeric & underscore).
+   Plus. Match 1 or more of the preceding token.
)
*   Star. Match 0 or more of the preceding token.
$   End. Matches the end of the string,
    or the end of a line if the multiline flag (m) is enabled.

Closes-Bug: #1509217

Change-Id: Ied5a259699237f47aa9e4b0c16c85cfe8a1eda15
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/51/303651/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """ Details on the REGEX used ^ Beginning. Matches the beginning of the string, or the beginning of a line if the multiline flag (m) is enabled. \w Word. Matches any word character (alphanumeric & underscore). + Plus. Match 1 or more of the preceding token. (?: Non-capturing group. Groups multiple tokens together without creating a capture group. [ Character set. Match any character in the set. - Character. Matches a "-" character (char code 45). Character. Matches a SPACE character (char code 32). ] \w Word. Matches any word character (alphanumeric & underscore). + Plus. Match 1 or more of the preceding token. ) * Star. Match 0 or more of the preceding token. $ End. Matches the end of the string, or the end of a line if the multiline flag (m) is enabled. The one used earlier: ^[\w\- ]+$ allowed spaces in the beginning and at the end of the keypair which gave birth to inadmissable key-pair results. """ KEYPAIR_NAME_REGEX = re.compile(r"^\w+(?:[- ]\w+)*$", re.UNICODE)

commit_message:
Correct the director in Customizing doc

After make theme changes, we have to re-generate the static
files, while I think the correct command should be
./run_tests.sh -m collecstatic
to overwrite the existing files.

Change-Id: I428bd058cd525cc4a70f62d299af4936c3d0511d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/87/293887/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Create project but no display and an error

When i press the create project button,there is no form appear
an error 'Recoverable error: Could not find default role
"_member_" in Keystone' occur
then i take keystoneclient's  roles into settings and get
from it,the settings set default role '_member_' which is not
in keystoneclient's roles

Change-Id: I83e5e7605c57253a7a5b9fa527337b1895af684c
Closes-Bug: #1064433

commit_message:
Splitting Out Connectors from connector.py

This is a larger refactor of the connector.py file. The goal is to
simplfy the file by moving the vendor connector classes to their own
files, and keep only the InitiatorConnector in the connector.py file.
The vendor specific connector tests are also split out into their own
files.

Change-Id: I020e75ca8cd8bec2ad1b38f3ade5cc1f63a4fee5
Implements: bp connector-refactor
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/74/307974/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_concurrency import processutils as putils from oslo_log import log as logging from os_brick.initiator import FCConnector as FibreChannelConnector from os_brick.initiator import linuxfc from os_brick.initiator import linuxscsi DEVICE_SCAN_ATTEMPTS_DEFAULT = 3 LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class FibreChannelConnectorS390X(FibreChannelConnector): """Connector class to attach/detach Fibre Channel volumes on S390X arch.""" def __init__(self, root_helper, driver=None, execute=putils.execute, use_multipath=False, device_scan_attempts=DEVICE_SCAN_ATTEMPTS_DEFAULT, *args, **kwargs): super(FibreChannelConnectorS390X, self).__init__( root_helper, driver=driver, execute=execute, device_scan_attempts=device_scan_attempts, *args, **kwargs) LOG.debug("Initializing Fibre Channel connector for S390") self._linuxscsi = linuxscsi.LinuxSCSI(root_helper, execute) self._linuxfc = linuxfc.LinuxFibreChannelS390X(root_helper, execute) self.use_multipath = use_multipath def set_execute(self, execute): super(FibreChannelConnectorS390X, self).set_execute(execute) self._linuxscsi.set_execute(execute) self._linuxfc.set_execute(execute) def _get_host_devices(self, possible_devs, lun): host_devices = [] for pci_num, target_wwn in possible_devs: target_lun = self._get_lun_string(lun) host_device = self._get_device_file_path( pci_num, target_wwn, target_lun) self._linuxfc.configure_scsi_device(pci_num, target_wwn, target_lun) host_devices.append(host_device) return host_devices def _get_lun_string(self, lun): target_lun = 0 if lun <= 0xffff: target_lun = "0x%04x000000000000" % lun elif lun <= 0xffffffff: target_lun = "0x%08x00000000" % lun return target_lun def _get_device_file_path(self, pci_num, target_wwn, target_lun): host_device = "/dev/disk/by-path/ccw-%s-zfcp-%s:%s" % ( pci_num, target_wwn, target_lun) return host_device def _remove_devices(self, connection_properties, devices): hbas = self._linuxfc.get_fc_hbas_info() ports = connection_properties['target_wwn'] possible_devs = self._get_possible_devices(hbas, ports) lun = connection_properties.get('target_lun', 0) target_lun = self._get_lun_string(lun) for pci_num, target_wwn in possible_devs: self._linuxfc.deconfigure_scsi_device(pci_num, target_wwn, target_lun)

commit_message:
Delete multiple objects from the container panel

Delete objects should have check box to select all.
Current code has mulitple selection of table row, but this
is not visible due to brower table content display.

Change-Id: Ieda7df0e8d236f7313765b0b313aa1f4c88a8aa9
Closes-Bug: #1462082

commit_message:
verify 'truncate' attr is for columns containing strings only

This will prevent throwing exception if applying truncate
attribute on columns that contain non-strings.
You can test this out by going to:
openstack_dashboard/dashboards/admin/flavors/tables.py#141
and adding truncate=2 to vcpus (Integer column) and visiting
Flavors table.

Change-Id: Ic92da3ca18f3e94e1be41738bcd1abb2d3c67cc1
Closes-Bug: #1369944

Show Public images first after subbitting creating

When i create an image (which is public) and submit the form.
The image list defaults back to the project image list rather

commit_message:
Angular Table Tutorial

This tutorial walks the developer through creation of the angular table.
It offers two approaches on table creation, quick and declarative, each
with pros and cons.

You can see the changes by clicking on gate-horizon-docs.
To test this patch locally:
1. run ./run_test.sh --docs
2. open doc/build/html/index.html

Change-Id: Ic79e4ea933f098f825691a8bc6d7bfabef25e08b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/07/314807/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
=================================== Tutorial: Building an Angular table =================================== This tutorial assumes you are familiar with how to build a panel. Refer to the :doc:`dasboard tutorial ` if you are building the panel in trunk or the :doc:`plugin tutorial ` if you are building the panel in a plugin. In this tutorial, we will show you two ways to create a table. The quick version will allow you to quickly tabulate your data while the declarative version will give you full control over the template. In doing so, we will also highlight why you might want to consider one approach over the other. The quick version ================= If you want to quickly tabulate your data and do as little work as possible, use the quick version. In addition to speed you extensibility for free. See :doc:`extending a workflow ` on how you can similarly extend the table's configurations. .. The source for the following diagram can be found at: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B5nlaOV3OEj5aElxYWNiemxvNDg/view?usp=sharing .. figure:: ../images/ngtable-quick.png :width: 100% :align: center :alt: Dynamic Table Relationships Before we dive into the code, it is important for us to understand the relationships between them. Take a moment to absorb it. In this tutorial, we will use a simplified example of the users table. The full code is available in trunk and on github. Lets dive in! table-config.service.js ----------------------- :: (function() { 'use strict'; angular .module('horizon.dashboard.identity.users') .factory('horizon.dashboard.identity.users.tableConfigService', tableConfigService); tableConfigService.$inject = [ 'horizon.dashboard.identity.basePath', 'horizon.framework.util.extensible.service' ]; function tableConfigService(basePath, extensibleService) { var config = { selectAll: true, expand: true, trackId: 'id', columns: [{ id: 'name', title: gettext('User Name'), priority: 1, sortDefault: true }] }; extensibleService(config, config.columns); return config; } })(); We declared that this table has exactly one column. Notice that this configuration object is extensible. This essentially allows plugin developers to add new columns displaying additional information without ever touching source. This will be a theme we revisit often since it is an extremely powerful pattern. table.controller.js ------------------- :: (function() { 'use strict'; angular .module('horizon.dashboard.identity.users') .controller('identityUsersTableController', identityUsersTableController); identityUsersTableController.$inject = [ 'horizon.dashboard.identity.users.tableConfigService' ]; function identityUsersTableController(config) { var ctrl = this; ctrl.users = []; ctrl.iusers = [ { name: 'horizon' }, { name: 'searchlight' }, ]; ctrl.userSession = {}; ctrl.checked = {}; ctrl.config = config; } })(); Normally, we perform policy checks and pull data through our REST apis. For the sake of simplicity, we will populate this table with mocked data. More importantly, we referenced the configuration object by assigning it to **ctrl.config**. table.html ---------- ::
Here we reference our controller via the ng-controller directive. The directive hz-dynamic-table saves us a lot of boilerplate code. All we need is to pass in a configuration object and items. It takes care of the rest! This concludes the first part of the tutorial. The declarative version ======================= We dont recommend using this approach unless you need absolute control over the visualization. Otherwise, this section serves as a good "under the hood" look at what is happening behind the scene. In the declarative example, you no longer use hz-dynamic-table or the table configuration. Instead, we will write our own view. table.controller.js ------------------- :: (function() { 'use strict'; angular .module('horizon.dashboard.identity.users') .controller('identityUsersTableController', identityUsersTableController); function identityUsersTableController() { var ctrl = this; ctrl.users = []; ctrl.iusers = [ { name: 'horizon' }, { name: 'searchlight' }, ]; ctrl.userSession = {}; ctrl.checked = {}; } })(); Notice that we are no longer referencing the table configuration. This is now done declaratively in the view. table.html ---------- ::
User Name
{$ user.name $}
This is an **extremely** simplified version to give you an idea of how to do it declaratively. The full example involves a myriad of smaller directives that adds functionality to the table. Examples include: checkboxes, details row, summary row, responsive columns, etc. The most important directive here is smart-table. We reference the controller and feed the items into st-table directly. In the table header, we declare our name column and in the body, we loop through our data to display the user's name. In its most basic form, this is essentially what hz-dynamic-table does for us. It abstracted these declarations into a table configuration that we control as a javascript object. If you are familiar with web development, this is just javascript and html. If you need finer control over your own view, just replace the HTML and include your own angular directives or jQuery widgets. As famously stated, with great power comes great responsbility. What you choose to do in your own plugin is entirely up to you but try to establish a pattern that will work well with horizon and other plugins. If you need a pointer or would like to discuss patterns, we are always available on IRC, feel free to reach out to one of us.s

commit_message:
Bump heatclient dependency to 1.0.0

We use event_utils.poll_for_events in our heat support, but a user needs
at least 1.0.0 for that to work properly.

Change-Id: Ic1c6d243d596947f7475f569c3b125130456a273

commit_message:
Change Layout of Path + Sub Title

With very long URI paths the wrapping either
looks weird or there is no charecter for it to
wrap on.

This moves the URI to its own line, and moves some
of the other elements aroud slightly.

Also changes the font of the subtitle to make it more apparent.

Change-Id: I36e7420224f69eaa5f4dceb18d910b40377b76c4

subject: Fix repo constraints construction and package installation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-03 02:31:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build/commit/afd513d1d1057d8d85ea3b3ead64b05870824f3c', 'message': "Fix repo constraints construction and package installation

The current repo build process has the following issues:

1. The constraints consruction doesn't properly handle two constraints
   which use the same name, but have different version specs. eg:
   dnspython===1.14.0
   dnspython3===1.12.0;python_version=='3.4'
   This is a problem in both the constraints construction, and
   in the testing.

2. The pip packages installed on the repo server in order to
   construct the repo do not respect the global pins or the upper
   constraint overrides.

3. The constraints are selected based on the requirements specified.
   This makes the process unnecessarily complex and hard to test.

4. The global pins are not applied to the constructed constraints,
   so the wrong packages get built and installed.

5. The tests aren't thoroughly checking that the constraints are
   correct.

This patch corrects all of these issues and hopefully makes the
mechanism for constructing constraints more readily apparent, and
therefore easier to maintain.

Change-Id: If52d073d43081468e2faf2cd063c4b211c29994f
Related-Bug: #1605846
Closes-Bug: #1609056

commit_message:
Fix repo constraints construction and package installation

The current repo build process has the following issues:

1. The constraints consruction doesn't properly handle two constraints
   which use the same name, but have different version specs. eg:
   ovs===2.5.0;python_version=='2.7'
   ovs===2.6.0.dev2;python_version=='3.4'
   This is a problem in both the constraints construction, and
   in the testing.

2. The pip packages installed on the repo server in order to
   construct the repo do not respect the global pins or the upper
   constraint overrides.

3. The constraints are selected based on the requirements specified.
   This makes the process unnecessarily complex and hard to test.

4. The global pins are not applied to the constructed constraints,
   so the wrong packages get built and installed.

5. The tests aren't thoroughly checking that the constraints are
   correct.

This patch corrects all of these issues and hopefully makes the
mechanism for constructing constraints more readily apparent, and
therefore easier to maintain.

Change-Id: If52d073d43081468e2faf2cd063c4b211c29994f
Related-Bug: #1605846
Closes-Bug: #1609056

commit_message:
Refactored the compute model and its elements

In this changeset, I refactored the whole Watcher codebase to
adopt a naming convention about the various elements of the
Compute model so that it reflects the same naming convention
adopted by Nova.

Change-Id: I28adba5e1f27175f025330417b072686134d5f51
Partially-Implements: blueprint cluster-model-objects-wrapper

added_lines: from watcher.decision_engine.model import element for resource_type in element.ResourceType: resource = element.Resource(resource_type.value) model.create_resource(resource) nodes = self.wrapper.get_compute_node_list() for h in nodes: # create node in cluster_model_collector node = element.ComputeNode() node.uuid = service.host node.hostname = h.hypervisor_hostname model.resource.memory.set_capacity(node, h.memory_mb) model.resource.disk.set_capacity(node, h.free_disk_gb) model.resource.disk_capacity.set_capacity(node, h.local_gb) model.resource.num_cores.set_capacity(node, h.vcpus) node.state = h.state node.status = h.status model.add_node(node) instances = self.wrapper.get_instances_by_node(str(service.host)) for inst in instances: # create instance in cluster_model_collector instance = element.Instance() instance.uuid = inst.id # nova/nova/compute/instance_states.py instance.state = getattr(inst, 'OS-EXT-STS:vm_state') self.wrapper.get_flavor_instance(inst, flavor_cache) model.resource.memory.set_capacity( instance, inst.flavor['ram']) model.resource.disk.set_capacity( instance, inst.flavor['disk']) model.resource.num_cores.set_capacity( instance, inst.flavor['vcpus']) model.get_mapping().map(node, instance) model.add_instance(instance)
deleted_lines: from watcher.decision_engine.model import hypervisor as obj_hypervisorfrom watcher.decision_engine.model import resource from watcher.decision_engine.model import vm as obj_vm for resource_type in resource.ResourceType: res = resource.Resource(resource_type.value) model.create_resource(res) hypervisors = self.wrapper.get_hypervisors_list() for h in hypervisors: # create hypervisor in cluster_model_collector hypervisor = obj_hypervisor.Hypervisor() hypervisor.uuid = service.host hypervisor.hostname = h.hypervisor_hostname model.resource.memory.set_capacity(hypervisor, h.memory_mb) model.resource.disk.set_capacity(hypervisor, h.free_disk_gb) model.resource.disk_capacity.set_capacity(hypervisor, h.local_gb) model.resource.num_cores.set_capacity(hypervisor, h.vcpus) hypervisor.state = h.state hypervisor.status = h.status model.add_hypervisor(hypervisor) vms = self.wrapper.get_vms_by_hypervisor(str(service.host)) for v in vms: # create VM in cluster_model_collector vm = obj_vm.VM() vm.uuid = v.id # nova/nova/compute/vm_states.py vm.state = getattr(v, 'OS-EXT-STS:vm_state') self.wrapper.get_flavor_instance(v, flavor_cache) model.resource.memory.set_capacity(vm, v.flavor['ram']) model.resource.disk.set_capacity(vm, v.flavor['disk']) model.resource.num_cores.set_capacity(vm, v.flavor['vcpus']) model.get_mapping().map(hypervisor, vm) model.add_vm(vm)

commit_message:
Move default network_interface logic in node object

This patch moves the default network_interface logic into the node
object using a field default value. This means if the network_interface
on a node object is ever set to None it'll calculate the default to
place into that field.

Change-Id: I753d969b31ba2d12df4db3fc95a7d9e9ca1e4df6
Partial-Bug: #1608511

commit_message:
Check response from version for auth required

If the version call requires auth, we need to catch that to understand
if we should use auth for making requests.  Previously the version api
call may have been open which allowed the CLI to make the call to
determine if auth should be used. If the version call itself requires
auth, then we need to check the response code to enable authentication
for the api requests.

Change-Id: Ie70d601eb4db4909e52e6afaa15cba6195f24045
Related-Bug: #1585137
(cherry picked from commit 72a7cd19e687460e7414b02960489fa422fe6fce)

commit_message:
Don't translate OS::Nova::Server image property to UUID

Ensure that when we specify an image by name, the OS::Nova::Server
resource looks only at the name when deciding whether the property has
changed on an update. Changes in Mitaka mean that the built-in plugin in
Heat translates the name to a UUID.

Change-Id: Ic7a17e35b455f515c4731d4e94401c8971e0ef4b
Closes-Bug: #1609020
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/45/350145/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def translation_rules(self, props): rules = super(ServerUpdateAllowed, self).translation_rules(props) return [r for r in rules if r.translation_path != [self.IMAGE]]

commit_message:
Implement "network rbac set" command

Add "network rbac set" command which just supports
setting a target project.
Also, This patch adds the doc, unit test and functional test.
But there is a bug of showing network RBAC
https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-openstacksdk/+bug/1608903
We need to skip the functional test before this bug fixed.

Change-Id: I756f448bb333cf1098a735e57a1c5dc4edf195d4
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-client-rbac

commit_message:
Support for Intel X710 NIC

One of our partners discovered that while Intel XL710 NICs are recognized
by deployed MOS 7.0 environment they can't be configured from Fuel even
when using Ubuntu bootstrap.

Change-Id: I7b69e8e74864949848aa14cf4c26f43190fa5ef9
Closes-Bug: #1536615

commit_message:
Setup upgrade levels for each fuel version

Setup upgrade levels block in nova.conf for each fuel version,
this is required for backward compatibility on RPC.

Change-Id: I6ccbc34457d11616b015cdb1e46e733b0b49ce58

commit_message:
Fix neutron migrations using raw sql queries

* create networksecuritybindings for each network,
if it isn't exists and set default value (True)
to port_security column

* update network_type and phisnet values for externalnetworks,
set them to default values for fuel-8 release
(network_type = flat phisnet=phisnet1)

Partial-Bug: 1601895
Change-Id: I9838befe52f7a412a70d223ccbde5a9ff7ce8281
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-octane refs/changes/74/342674/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def fix_neutron_migrations(node): sql_qs = [ "insert into networksecuritybindings " "select id, 1 " "from networks " "where id not in (select network_id from networksecuritybindings);", "update ml2_network_segments " "set network_type='flat',physical_network='physnet1' " "where network_id in (select network_id from externalnetworks);", ] for sql in sql_qs: ssh.call(["mysql", "neutron", "-c", sql], node=node, parse_levels=True) fix_neutron_migrations(node)

commit_message:
update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0. Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I27348462a21daab479d76b24b48e3a4e017504cc
(cherry picked from commit 0b59a910fb8d614f9503b7921edf196e6f908a37)

commit_message:
Add a hook to process newly created engines

Add on_engine_create argument to transaction_context to enable users
to take some actions with newly created engines. Main intended usage
is providing oslo.db and osprofiler users with a way to hook them
together without making them depend on each other.

Closes-bug: #1600739

Change-Id: I78bef4979c2000d05658ce17d0348cd0a10c24d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db refs/changes/60/340260/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osprofiler.opts import osprofiler.sqlalchemy import sqlalchemy args = self._args_for_conf(self._engine_cfg, conf) if conf and 'profiler' in conf: args['profiler'] = osprofiler.opts.is_db_trace_enabled(conf) else: args['profiler'] = False return args engine_kwargs = engine_kwargs.copy() profiler = engine_kwargs.pop('profiler') if profiler: osprofiler.sqlalchemy.add_tracing(sqlalchemy, engine, "oslo.db")

commit_message:
Changed backup-restore to accept backup name

Edited do_backup_restore function to accept the name of the backup
as well as its id. Changed the test to comply with this.

DocImpact

Closes-Bug: #1604892

Change-Id: Iaec69dd053a119366fa5a8437701a6f7c3da2235

commit_message:
Prepare for fuel-devops 2.9.22 API changes

Use intermediate layers while test adoptation in process.
Mark as deprecated methods, which is completely covered by
devops implementation.

Change-Id: I4cb87cc1d5f7184cd5400a5f03358068e528d93a
(cherry picked from commit 754b023)

commit_message:
Fix share migration test with snapshot support

Test 'test_migrate_share_with_snapshot_v2_5' validates that
share migration returns an error when a share has a snapshot
created, but to do so, it tries to create a snapshot, which
would fail in a backend that does not support snapshot.
This fix adds a validation that skips the test in this situation.

Change-Id: Icd6b04266ac2de83747b99295cb3538967922d65
Closes-bug: #1608293
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/82/349982/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not CONF.share.capability_snapshot_support: raise self.skipException("Snapshot support is disabled. Skipping.")

commit_message:
Delete openstack/common from the exclude list of flake8 in tox

The directory openstack/common was used to keep codes from
oslo-incubator, we have retired oslo-incubator, so don't use
this directory any more.

Change-Id: Id64c88c9c08b26b8728d5c87798051d4061ccb59

commit_message:
Generate CephX keys and FSID regardless of CephStorageCount

This will change the client behavior so that it always generate
the CephX keys and the cluster FSID regardless of which value is
given as CephStorageCount, to cope with hyperconverged scenarios.

Change-Id: I64acd6a4ed1b56fddfd366b5846dba3c22300df4
Related-Bug: 1601864
(cherry picked from commit 694d097c5fd3db8026b43ea577dc0548fcd6ca4e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/60/350460/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if stack_is_new: parameters.update({ 'CephClusterFSID': six.text_type(uuid.uuid1()), 'CephMonKey': utils.create_cephx_key(), 'CephAdminKey': utils.create_cephx_key(), 'CephClientKey': utils.create_cephx_key() })
deleted_lines: if int(parameters.get('CephStorageCount', 0)) > 0: if stack_is_new: parameters.update({ 'CephClusterFSID': six.text_type(uuid.uuid1()), 'CephMonKey': utils.create_cephx_key(), 'CephAdminKey': utils.create_cephx_key(), 'CephClientKey': utils.create_cephx_key() })

commit_message:
Remove an outdated directory in tox.ini

The directory openstack/common from the exclude list of
flake8 in tox.ini was used to keep codes from oslo-incubator,
but oslo-incubator was retired, so don't use this directory
any more.

Change-Id: If1ea5dc167cfe4a09aad413b9eab0af807ebe603
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/83/350383/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: exclude = .git,.tox,dist,doc,*lib/python*,*egg,build,tools

commit_message:
Remove 'default' theme styles

The default theme houses lots of styles that intended to maintain
style parity with legacy Horizon during the themability effort.
Because Horizon is mostly ingesting native bootstrap now, we can
just remove the 'default' theme entirely and use vanilla Bootstrap
styles for Basic Horizon moving forward.

implements: blueprint horizon-bootstrap-styles
Change-Id: I76f48265321037d1bc71b52cd7a86531548816ba

commit_message:
Refactor deallocate_fixed tests to use one mock approach instead of three

This cleans up the tests added/edited in the last patch per feedback.
Instead of mock, stubs, and mox, this just uses mock.

If False, volumes attached to an instance must be in the same availability zone in Cinder as the instance availability zone in Nova. commit_message:
Fix AddressPool._safe_create_network

- transaction.atomic was used improperly.
  transaction.rollback() will be called at atomic.__exit__
  in case of error
- Added DevopsError for duplicate names and networks
- Added unit tests

Closes-Bug: #1598141
Closes-Bug: #1597025
Closes-bug: #1607342
Change-Id: I024c29761048447446a09ac4439cca66e60b11d4

commit_message:
glusterfs_native: fix parsing of the dynamic-auth option

The full name of the 'dynamic-auth' GlusterFS option
is 'server.dynamic-auth'. When we started to make use
of it in https://review.openstack.org/229409, we just
used its short form, 'dynamic-auth'. That actually
*should* work but due to some weakness in the GlusterFS
instrumentation code, it doesn't.

Fix the situation for now by using the full option
name. We also take the opportunity to remove some
redundant checks from the respective option handling
code.

Change-Id: I6f30060cec38733afa1211cb8e7bc57b66dead34
Closes-Bug: #1506577
(cherry picked from commit c38d4969533efbd99e586f935edddf10a63e64a4)

commit_message:
Add direct_use=False flag to constructor of novaclient

As we directly use novaclient class with particular version,
we need to path direct_use=False to avoid fails.

Change-Id: Ieb3dcd2b48a172a4e7ad55e44dcdf6329c8bcb0c
Closes-Bug: #1603976
(cherry picked from commit a9a645aa34b2cbf7816b933294f2ac6bc88ebb86)

commit_message:
Enhance notification doc generation with samples

Until now the notification devref only contained a link to the sample file
and that link did only exist after the sample file was merged.
This is suboptimal as the locally generated doc might be incomplete.

This patch changes the doc to contain the content of the sample file.

Change-Id: I4343a2feb13de8b614e8d42d5f1db14102ab492e

commit_message:
Add note about network_interface migration to release notes

Adds to existing release note about how network_interface is set, to
remind people to check the logic and configs to make sure they get the
expected result.

Closes-Bug: #1608511
Change-Id: Ief53e2c9497392a08deb0a7197bb7d49e4ff2887
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/46/349546/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Note that ``[DEFAULT]default_network_interface`` must be set in the configuration file for both the API and conductor hosts. The network interface will be set for all nodes without network_interface already set via a database migration. This will be set following the logic above. When running database migrations for an existing deployment, it's important to check the above configuration options to ensure the existing nodes will have the expected network_interface.

_some_ sanity checking.

commit_message:
Add server name verification in instance search

There are Nova API calls that can accept a server name
as a regex parameter. For example, if the command
'nova list --name <some_pattern>' is invoked with
an incorrect value of the pattern, the nova-api makes
a request to database and returns Http 500 error. Seems
it's not convenient.

This fix checks the pattern. If it isn't correct,
the nova-api returns error 400 with a prompt of a bad regex.

Change-Id: Iad63c668d09ec6a82ace29700fb4949c1acfbe1c
Closes-Bug: #1603728
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/45/344945/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import re # Verify the value of the 'name' option is a correct regex. if 'name' in search_opts: try: re.compile(search_opts['name']) except re.error: msg = _("The regex for '--name' option is incorrect") raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg)

commit_message:
devstackgaterc: Exclude test_dhcp_port_status_active

This test is not appropriate for midonet deployment without dhcp agent.

Note: The full path of the test in question is:
neutron.tests.tempest.api.admin.test_dhcp_agent_scheduler.DHCPAgentSchedulersTestJSON.test_dhcp_port_status_active

Also, disable a few unrelated failing tests for now, so that this commit
can pass the gate.  I'll fix them one by one later.  (See Related-Bug)

Closes-Bug: #1608763
Related-Bug: #1608312
Related-Bug: #1608314

commit_message:
Remove network_device_mtu

network_device_mtu was deprecated in mitaka  and has now been completely
removed from neutron for newton. This patch removes all references.

In this patchset, I fixed them in the unit tests.

subject: Default image.size to 0 when extracting v1 image attributes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-26 22:34:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0b6acb024cb1484cc1962373071849c3b70829c3', 'message': "Default image.size to 0 when extracting v1 image attributes

When we snapshot a non-volume-backed instance, we create an
image in nova.compute.api.API._create_image and set some
values from the instance but 'size' isn't one of them.

Later in the virt driver's snapshot method, at least for
libvirt, it gets the snapshot image from the image API (glance)
and when using glance v1 (use_glance_v1=True) the _extract_attributes
method in nova.image.glance pulls the attributes out of the v1 image
response to the form that nova expects. This code assumes that
the 'size' attribute is set on the image, which for a snapshot image
it might not be (yet anyway). This results in an AttributeError.

This change defaults the size attribute value to 0 if it's not set.
If it is set, but to None, we still use 0 as before.

This was never a problem in unit tests because the TestConversions
unit test creates a fake v1 image response but all of the values
in the image dict have a default value of None because of how
dict.fromkeys works. As part of this change, that test is changed
to pop the 'size' attribute from the fake image response dict/object
to expose the bug and demonstrate the fix.

Change-Id: I14b0e44a7268231c2b19f013b563f0b8f09c2e88
Closes-Bug: #1606707
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-27 20:46:29.000000000', 'files': ['nova/image/glance.py', 'nova/tests/unit/image/test_glance.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7a16c754fb49615b802e6b8f3d886847c168bd2a', 'message': "Default image.size to 0 when extracting v1 image attributes

response to the form that nova expects. This code assumes that
the 'size' attribute is set on the image, which for a snapshot image
it might not be (yet anyway). This results in an AttributeError.

This change defaults the size attribute value to 0 if it's not set.
If it is set, but to None, we still use 0 as before.

Change-Id: I14b0e44a7268231c2b19f013b563f0b8f09c2e88
Closes-Bug: #1606707

commit_message:
Default image.size to 0 when extracting v1 image attributes

When we snapshot a non-volume-backed instance, we create an
image in nova.compute.api.API._create_image and set some
values from the instance but 'size' isn't one of them.

Later in the virt driver's snapshot method, at least for
libvirt, it gets the snapshot image from the image API (glance)
and when using glance v1 (use_glance_v1=True) the _extract_attributes
method in nova.image.glance pulls the attributes out of the v1 image
response to the form that nova expects. This code assumes that
the 'size' attribute is set on the image, which for a snapshot image
it might not be (yet anyway). This results in an AttributeError.

This change defaults the size attribute value to 0 if it's not set.
If it is set, but to None, we still use 0 as before.

Change-Id: I14b0e44a7268231c2b19f013b563f0b8f09c2e88
Closes-Bug: #1606707
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/71/347571/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(mriedem): fromkeys defaults all values in the dict to # None which is not correct for 'size' so pop that out. raw.pop('size')

commit_message:
Validate node id for log handler

This change updates the log handler to validate that the node id being
passed in is an integer. If it is not an integer, the response will be a
400.

Change-Id: Ida7a18a7261bf7fa98518a059d1de42690382d79
Closes-Bug: #1585160
(cherry picked from commit 65979423b625b5665a69a588ac96ac29a71ea5db)

commit_message:
Do not print unhandled exception if in production

This change removes the printing of unhandled exceptions when not in
development mode. We should never return the unhandled exception
information when not in development mode.

Logging nailgun exceptions
Now there is a special "processor" devoted to this

Change-Id: I820f5682d0fac292722a9f205965516771333a4d
Closes-Bug: #1585160
(cherry picked from commit c61fbc616fc6763c358ad70dac37341f65ddcb19)

commit_message:
Fix the issue introduced by Neutron config file refactorying

1.What is the problem
core_opts has been moved from neutron/common/config.py to
neutron/conf/common.py, the migration leads the py27 test failured
in tricircle/tests/base.py.

2.What's need to be fixed:
import common.py from neutron/conf/common.py instead from
from neutron/common/config.py

3.What is the purpose of this patch set:
fix the py27 check and gate test error introduced by Neutron
config file refactorying.

Change-Id: Icab2d6a2e25cc3387e5ee9951cc0b53491e012ee
Signed-off-by: joehuang <joehuang@huawei.com>

deleted_lines: from neutron.common import config for opt in config.core_opts:

commit_message:
Remove additional purge test

We recently added a new integration test for purge to check purge per
project. It doesn't provide much more testing, and we can't actually
have 2 purge tests because they can't run in parallel to each other, so
let's remove it for now.

Change-Id: I9f0b97adae9ea532bc2453441c327e30b849d006
Closes-Bug: #1608910

commit_message:
Remove unused validation code for quota_sets

The values of quota_sets are validated on JSON-Schema before the
API operation, so the validation code is never used.
This patch removes the code for its cleanup.

Change-Id: I6b2278ecb7b216ad02220dad0647c0847513604d

Remove leftover list_opts entry points

All remaining list_opts methods come from nova.conf.opts
now so remove the last remaining unused (nonexistent)
list_opts registrations.

commit_message:
Remove nova.cache_utils oslo.config.opts entrypoint

There was never a list_opts method in nova.cache_utils,
and the options registeration was moved to nova.conf.cache
in 466bce576a69d170f1ef08264da7e72ac4a150fb so we can
cleanup the entrypoint.

Change-Id: If02620752c1bb018117f2c6755d9b9661185e4d6

Remove neutronv2.api oslo.config.opt entry point

list_opts was moved from neutronv2.api to nova.conf.neutron
in 1b8b0834a07b857ffd9b743e89caf9b604d7f609 so we can cleanup
this broken entry point.

commit_message:
Bump API version number and date

As a result of commit I37136f79488d7469f0b8b24e3f5628899e40cac0,
the API version for v3 is now 3.7. This patch also updates the
API version updated date to that of the expected release date of
Newton.

Change-Id: I6509f4c5f2eb530c816490037fd64ed47ba0fdc0

commit_message:
rt: remove unused image_meta parameter

The image_meta parameter in _update_usage_from_migration was made
vestigial in change 7fd3032f39cc6cc9b8e87834aa037bc4fb5e5620 so
this removes it.

commit_message:
Reminder that release notes are built from commits

This patch introduces a new tools/releasenotes_tox.sh script for the
tox -e releasenotes test environment. It will detect when there are
uncommitted release notes and print a reminder to commit them.

Change-Id: I54af12d7eb20b37263e23443900745884cffacea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/87/338487/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: commands = bash -c tools/releasenotes_tox.sh
deleted_lines: commands = rm -rf releasenotes/build sphinx-build -a -E -W -d releasenotes/build/doctrees -b html releasenotes/source releasenotes/build/html

subject: Use ovo in test_obj_make_compatible()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-25 22:31:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1ffb03ee12ef0ff049a2040f9477fd4924187c6f', 'message': 'Pass args/kwargs in test_obj_make_compatible

The ServiceStatusPayload object requires args to be passed to its
__init__() function. test_obj_make_compatible just calls __init__() on
obj_class on all classes in the registry, so there needs to be a way to
build args/kwargs based on what obj_class is. This change creates 2
dictionaries: one to hold args, and one to hold kwargs. The key for both
dictionaries is the object class, and the values are the args/kwargs
that need to get passed to __init__().

If the class is not in the args/kwargs dictionary, [] is returned by
default for args, and {} is returned by default for kwargs. That way if
they need nothing special, *[] is the equivalent of sending no args, and
**{} is the equivalent of sending no kwargs.

The test_obj_make_compatible() function was also changed to check
compatibilities from all previous versions to the current version,
inclusively. That way, when we get an initial version of another object
that requires an arg/kwarg to __init__(), it will be found on the first
version instead of when the version is bumped. This is also the way the
oslo.versionedobjects fixture tests object compatibilities.

Change-Id: Ie127f55f2e5bcd383796ff51253cf1091be16c98
Fixes-Bug: #1537882
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-01-26 14:55:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ea76285c7cd1e98a1caa71ee026697a885852b75', 'message': 'Pass args/kwargs in test_obj_make_compatible

dictionaries is the object class, and the values are the args/kwargs
that need to get passed to __init__().

If the class is not in the args/kwargs dictionary, [] is returned by
default for args, and {} is returned by default for kwargs. That way if
they need nothing special, *[] is the equivalent of sending no args, and
**{} is the equivalent of sending no kwargs.

The test_obj_make_compatible() function was also changed to check
compatibilities from all previous versions to the current version,
inclusively. That way, when we get an initial version of another object
that requires an arg/kwarg to __init__(), it will be found on the first
version instead of when the version is bumped. This is also the way the
oslo.versionedobjects fixture tests object compatibilities.

Change-Id: Ie127f55f2e5bcd383796ff51253cf1091be16c98

commit_message:
Use ovo in test_obj_make_compatible()

o.vo has a fixture for testing compatibility routines. This changes the
nova unit tests to use that compatibility testing on all objects. In the
original nova test, the versions tested were from 1.0 to 1.(x-1), where
1.x is the current version. o.vo's fixture tests from 1.0 to 1.x, which
should be a no-op, but is also a good thing to test (if we can't convert
1.x to 1.x, that's a bad thing).

o.vo also had an enhancement where it passed args and kwargs to __init__
in the different objects, which was a bug in nova, but using that
fixture allows us to also close the nova bug. This change in o.vo was
I62646b99adca47a9c9fe0f466f7a23ac8fa4553e.

Change-Id: Ie127f55f2e5bcd383796ff51253cf1091be16c98
Closes-Bug: #1537882
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/99/272299/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Hold a dictionary of args/kwargs that need to get passed into # __init__() for specific classes. The key in the dictionary is # the obj_class that needs the init args/kwargs. init_args = {objects.ServiceStatusPayload: [objects.Service()]} init_kwargs = {} args = init_args.get(obj_class, []) kwargs = init_kwargs.get(obj_class, {}) for n in range(version[1] + 1): obj_class(*args, **kwargs).obj_to_primitive( target_version=test_version, version_manifest=versions)

subject: Validate pci_passthrough_whitelist when starting n-cpu
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-14 17:40:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/98a8463f9c4f0c2dd2e4375795a51683ded0fcc5', 'message': 'WIP: Validate pci_passthrough_whitelist when starting n-cpu

Loading up CONF.pci_passthrough_whitelist in the Whitelist
object performs a bunch of validation and can fail in several
different ways (invalid json, invalid values, invalid combinations
of keys, devices not found, etc). This happens today when
creating the PciDevTracker in the ResourceTracker when updating
available resources. If the configuration is bad, it kills the
periodic task to update available resources on the compute node.

We should just load up the pci_passthrough_whitelist (if set)
when starting the nova-compute service so we can fail fast and
kill the service on any misconfiguration rather than run with
a broken service.

Change-Id: If50fb837b490042bb5ef20e9ad843b28f871a44e

commit_message:
Validate pci_passthrough_whitelist when starting n-cpu

Loading up CONF.pci_passthrough_whitelist in the Whitelist
object performs a bunch of validation and can fail in several
different ways (invalid json, invalid values, invalid combinations
of keys, devices not found, etc). This happens today when
creating the PciDevTracker in the ResourceTracker when updating
available resources. If the configuration is bad, it kills the
periodic task to update available resources on the compute node.

We should just load up the pci_passthrough_whitelist (if set)
when starting the nova-compute service so we can fail fast and
kill the service on any misconfiguration rather than run with
a broken service.

Change-Id: If50fb837b490042bb5ef20e9ad843b28f871a44e
Closes-Bug: #1603034
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/01/342301/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.pci import whitelist if CONF.pci_passthrough_whitelist: # Simply loading the PCI passthrough whitelist will do a bunch of # validation that would otherwise wait until the PciDevTracker is # constructed when updating available resources for the compute # node(s) in the resource tracker, effectively killing that task. # So load up the whitelist when starting the compute service to # flush any invalid configuration early so we can kill the service # if the configuration is wrong. whitelist.Whitelist(CONF.pci_passthrough_whitelist)

commit_message:
Move Assertion API to its own file

Change I2423030bd0849c051d22f63bf60b6a5f41f72574 migrated Federation
api-ref docs into keystone repository.

Moving Assertion API to its own file is one of the TODO comments left
there, which is being addressed in this change.

Change-Id: I0ad565619744eb7f7b3c2fb33971d8d8ab4e22ea

commit_message:
Some migrations tests incorrectly ref S3 for Swift

There were some notes on the test_migrations that referred to swift
specific tests as S3 URIs. This commit simply corrects those notes.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Iec8f905b31f80e3e94c3f5f0adc7e53de837ffdb

commit_message:
Expose guest CPU instruction set extensions

Partial implementation of blueprint expose-guest-cpu-instruction-set-extensions

Change-Id: I4d7ed3572b159af36e0c8885787b0897031c0382
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/88/298188/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================================== Expose supported guest CPU instruction set extensions ===================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/expose-guest-cpu-instruction-set-extensions.rst There isn't a way guarantee the guest can get specific CPU set extensions which required by image or flavor. This spec aims to expose the guest CPU set extenions based on the propose of host capabilities. Problem description =================== Currently nova exposes host CPU instruction set extensions from compute node in the host state, and there is filter `ComputeCapabilitiesFilter` can implement the scheduling based on the reported host CPU instruction set extensions. But there are limits on this way: * The instruction set extensions exposed to guest may be not equal to host CPU instruction set extensions. It depends on hypervisor configuration, the guest CPU instruction set extensions may be just a subset of host CPU capabilities. * Image provider is more clear the required CPU capabilities for application which integrated in the image. Image provider hope list the required CPU capabilities in the image, and nova will boot up an instance with correct host and get the required cpu capabilities. Use Cases ---------- * Image provider want to specify the a list of CPU instruction set extensions which required by image. * Administrator want to limit the CPU instruction set extensions which allowed to be choiced by image provider. Proposed change =============== This spec proposes to report supported guest CPU instruction set extensions. The new field ``hw_guest_cpu_instruction_set_extensions`` will be added to ``HostCapabilities`` object. The instruction set extension of CPU will be stored in this field as a set of enum. If this field isn't set, that means the host didn't support report the CPU instruction set extensions or the host CPU didn't have the concept about CPU instruction set extension. The valid values for the new field are coming from the CIM definition about CIM_ProcessorAllocationSettingData class's InstructionSetExtensionName property [1]. And without the DMTF prefix and case insensitive. So for AVX, it should be ``x86:avx``. The virt driver should map their extension name to this list. Image provider can list the required CPU instruction set extensions in the image property ``hw:guest_cpu_instruction_set_extensions``. Administrator also can limit CPU instruction set extensions which image provider can choice by specified allowed extensions in the extra spec ``hw_guest_cpu_instruction_set_extensions`` And this will exposed in the host_capabilities field of hypervisor API by a new microversion. Alternatives ------------ For using host aggregate, it still hard to finish this use-case: * ``AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation`` doesn't work for a list value. * There isn't way limit image properties based on flavor extra specs. This also can become quite difficult when trying to deploy instances requiring multiple other capabilities. Data model impact ----------------- New field ``hw_guest_cpu_instruction_set_extensions`` will be added to ``HostCapabilities`` object. REST API impact --------------- The new capabilities will be added to ``host_capabilities`` field of ``os-hypervisors`` API with new microversion. `GET /os-hypervisors/detail` Reponse body:: { "hypervisors": [ { "cpu_info": "{cpu_info}", "current_workload": 0, "status": "enabled", "state": "up", "disk_available_least": 0, "host_ip": "1.1.1.1", "host_capabilities": {"hw_machine_type": ["fake_type_1", "fake_type_2"], "hw_guest_cpu_instruction_set_extensions": ["x86:AVX", "x86:AVX2", "x86:SSE3", ...]}, "free_disk_gb": 1028, "free_ram_mb": 7680, "hypervisor_hostname": "fake-mini", "hypervisor_type": "fake", "hypervisor_version": 1000, "id": 1, "local_gb": 1028, "local_gb_used": 0, "memory_mb": 8192, "memory_mb_used": 512, "running_vms": 0, "service": { "host": "e6a37ee802d74863ab8b91ade8f12a67", "id": 2, "disabled_reason": null }, "vcpus": 1, "vcpus_used": 0 } ] } `GET /os-hypervisors/{hypervisor_id}` Reponse body:: { "hypervisor": { "cpu_info": "{cpu_info}", "state": "up", "status": "enabled", "current_workload": 0, "disk_available_least": 0, "host_ip": "1.1.1.1", "host_capabilities": {"hw_machine_type": ["fake_type_1", "fake_type_2"], "hw_guest_cpu_instruction_set_extensions": ["x86:AVX", "x86:AVX2", "x86:SSE3", ...]}, "free_disk_gb": 1028, "free_ram_mb": 7680, "hypervisor_hostname": "fake-mini", "hypervisor_type": "fake", "hypervisor_version": 1000, "id": 1, "local_gb": 1028, "local_gb_used": 0, "memory_mb": 8192, "memory_mb_used": 512, "running_vms": 0, "service": { "host": "043b3cacf6f34c90a7245151fc8ebcda", "id": 2, "disabled_reason": null }, "vcpus": 1, "vcpus_used": 0 } } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== This spec only implement the libvirt driver. For other virt driver, the new field ``hw_guest_cpu_instruction_set_extensions`` of ``HostCapabilities`` will not be set. libvirt driver -------------- There are two options used to control the guest CPU model ``cpu_mode`` and ``cpu_model``. Based on these two options to get guest CPU supported CPU instruction set extensions. * When the ``cpu_mode`` is ``host-model``, ``host-passthrough`` and ``none``, the host's cpu instruction set extensions will be reported as guest's. * When the ``cpu_mode`` is ``custom``, the value of ``cpu_model`` and libvirt API ``baselineCPU`` will be used to get the custom cpu model's cpu instruction set extensions. Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Alex Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com> Work Items ---------- * Add the ability for each capability can custom the way of merging image properties and flavor extra specs. * Add new field ``hw_guest_cpu_instruction_set_extensions`` to ``HostCapabilities`` object. * Expose guest cpu instruction set extensions for libvirt driver. * Expose new capabilities in the ``os-hypervisors`` API with new microversion. Dependencies ============ Expose host capabilities: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/expose-host-capabilities Testing ======= * Unit tests. * API Sample tests. * Tempest tests. Documentation Impact ==================== The new host capabilities that can be scheduled using The new nova API microversion will have to be documented. References ========== [1] The definition of InstructionSetExtensionName http://schemas.dmtf.org/wbem/cim-html/2/CIM_ProcessorAllocationSettingData.html History =======

commit_message:
Ensure required interfaces list is correct

When a subset of cinder services is enabled, we don't expect all interfaces
to exist and unexpected errors/warnings to be reported in workload-status.

Change-Id: I9d5b6149c847c972d6fb0cfaf697d2885bbbf5c1
Closes-Bug: 1606559

commit_message:
Implement retries for SSH check

Most of often when Ansible can't connect to the container, it has
started up and appears to still be in the process of completing
the startup.

This implements retries for the SSH connection to increase the
chance of success.

Change-Id: I55f95628905180add79e2548e0553ca15dd19e2b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_container_create refs/changes/48/350448/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Allow policy file to not exist

Now that policy rules can be registered in code there is a desire to run
projects without a policy file. However oslo.policy assumed a policy
file would exist and would raise an error if it could not be found. This
changes that behavior to not error if a policy file is not found.

Because there are now tools which can generate policy files which list
the defaults, or list the effective policy there is no requirement that
a policy file be used in order to examine the policy that is in use. So
it should be possible to run without one.

Change-Id: Ia82df77f7a65aa1f3e3eaa7ed949103fa73fb603
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy refs/changes/32/341732/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class EnforcerNoPolicyFileTest(base.PolicyBaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(EnforcerNoPolicyFileTest, self).setUp() def check_loaded_files(self, filenames): self.assertEqual( [self.get_config_file_fullname(n) for n in filenames], self.enforcer._loaded_files ) def test_load_rules(self): # Check that loading rules with no policy file does not error self.enforcer.load_rules(True) self.assertIsNotNone(self.enforcer.rules) self.assertEqual(0, len(self.enforcer.rules)) def test_opts_registered(self): self.enforcer.register_default(policy.RuleDefault(name='admin', check_str='is_admin:False')) self.enforcer.register_default(policy.RuleDefault(name='owner', check_str='role:owner')) self.enforcer.load_rules(True) self.assertEqual({}, self.enforcer.file_rules) self.assertEqual('role:owner', str(self.enforcer.rules['owner'])) self.assertEqual('is_admin:False', str(self.enforcer.rules['admin'])) def test_load_directory(self): self.create_config_file('policy.d/a.conf', POLICY_JSON_CONTENTS) self.create_config_file('policy.d/b.conf', POLICY_B_CONTENTS) self.enforcer.load_rules(True) self.assertIsNotNone(self.enforcer.rules) loaded_rules = jsonutils.loads(str(self.enforcer.rules)) self.assertEqual('role:fakeB', loaded_rules['default']) self.assertEqual('is_admin:True', loaded_rules['admin']) self.check_loaded_files([ 'policy.d/a.conf', 'policy.d/b.conf', ])

commit_message:
[config-ref] reorder drivers by community and vendors

Docs team focuses on the drivers by open source software.
Also, docs for a few verdor drivers are not maintained well.
To highlight the OSS drivers, move them up.

Change-Id: I1760af95d8eafa0bbb3e0a1e9617f20dcbf6ddaf

commit_message:
Openstack performance tests results

Change-Id: I4623a1f54a0e476ffd958d47845a05c4f32be948
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/performance-docs refs/changes/81/330581/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _Measuring_performance_of_openstack_services: ********************************************************* Results of measuring performance of Openstack Services ********************************************************* :Abstract: This document includes performance test results of OpenStack services. All tests have been performed regarding :ref:`Measuring_performance_of_openstack_services` Environment description ======================= Environment contains 5 types of servers: - rally node - controller node - compute-osd node - compute node - osd node .. table:: Amount of servers each role +------------+--------------+ |Role |Servers count | +============+==============+ |rally |1 | +------------+--------------+ |controller |3 | +------------+--------------+ |compute |176 | +------------+--------------+ |compute-osd |20 | +------------+--------------+ |osd |0 | +------------+--------------+ Hardware configuration of each server ------------------------------------- All servers have same configuration describing in table below .. table:: Description of servers hardware +-------+----------------+-------------------------------+ |server |vendor,model |HP,DL380 Gen9 | +-------+----------------+-------------------------------+ |CPU |vendor,model |Intel,E5-2680 v3 | | +----------------+-------------------------------+ | |processor_count |2 | | +----------------+-------------------------------+ | |core_count |12 | | +----------------+-------------------------------+ | |frequency_MHz |2500 | +-------+----------------+-------------------------------+ |RAM |vendor,model |HP,752369-081 | | +----------------+-------------------------------+ | |amount_MB |262144 | +-------+----------------+-------------------------------+ |NETWORK|interface_name |p1p1 | | +----------------+-------------------------------+ | |vendor,model |Intel,X710 Dual Port | | +----------------+-------------------------------+ | |bandwidth |10G | +-------+----------------+-------------------------------+ |STORAGE|dev_name |/dev/sda | | +----------------+-------------------------------+ | |vendor,model | | raid10 - HP P840 | | | | | 12 disks EH0600JEDHE | | +----------------+-------------------------------+ | |SSD/HDD |HDD | | +----------------+-------------------------------+ | |size | 3,6TB | +-------+----------------+-------------------------------+ Network configuration of each server --------------------------------------------------------------------- All servers have same network configuration: .. image:: configs/Network_Scheme.png :alt: Network Scheme of the environment Here is the part of switch configuration for each switch port which connected to ens1f0 interface of a server: .. code:: bash switchport mode trunk switchport trunk native vlan 600 switchport trunk allowed vlan 600-602,630-649 spanning-tree port type edge trunk spanning-tree bpduguard enable no snmp trap link-status Software configuration on servers with controller, compute and compute-osd roles -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- .. table:: Services on servers by role +------------+----------------------------+ |Role |Service name | +============+============================+ |controller || horizon | | || keystone | | || nova-api | | || nava-scheduler | | || nova-cert | | || nova-conductor | | || nova-consoleauth | | || nova-consoleproxy | | || cinder-api | | || cinder-backup | | || cinder-scheduler | | || cinder-volume | | || glance-api | | || glance-glare | | || glance-registry | | || neutron-dhcp-agent | | || neutron-l3-agent | | || neutron-metadata-agent | | || neutron-openvswitch-agent | | || neutron-server | | || heat-api | | || heat-api-cfn | | || heat-api-cloudwatch | | || ceph-mon | | || rados-gw | | || heat-engine | +------------+----------------------------+ |compute || nova-compute | | || neutron-l3-agent | | || neutron-metadata-agent | | || neutron-openvswitch-agent | +------------+----------------------------+ |compute-osd || nova-compute | | || neutron-l3-agent | | || neutron-metadata-agent | | || neutron-openvswitch-agent | | || ceph-osd | +------------+----------------------------+ |osd |ceph-osd | +------------+----------------------------+ .. table:: Software version on servers with controller, compute and compute-osd roles +------------+-------------------+ |Software |Version | +============+===================+ |OpenStack |Mitaka | +------------+-------------------+ |Ceph |Hammer | +------------+-------------------+ |Ubuntu |Ubuntu 14.04.3 LTS | +------------+-------------------+ You can find outputs of some commands and /etc folder in the following archives: | :download:`controller-1.tar.gz <configs/controller-1.tar.gz>` | :download:`controller-2.tar.gz <configs/controller-2.tar.gz>` | :download:`controller-3.tar.gz <configs/controller-3.tar.gz>` | :download:`compute-1.tar.gz <configs/compute-1.tar.gz>` | :download:`compute-osd-1.tar.gz <configs/compute-osd-1.tar.gz>` Software configuration on servers with rally role ------------------------------------------------- On this server should be installed Rally. How to do it you can find in `Rally installation documentation`_ .. table:: Software version on server with rally role +------------+-------------------+ |Software |Version | +============+===================+ |Rally |0.4.0 | +------------+-------------------+ |Ubuntu |Ubuntu 14.04.3 LTS | +------------+-------------------+ Testing process =============== 1. Create work directory on server with Rally role. In future we will call that directory as WORK_DIR 2. Create directory "plugins" in WORK_DIR and copy to that directory :download:`nova_scale.py <configs/nova_scale.py>` plugin. 3. Create directory "scenarios" in WORK_DIR and copy to that directory :download:`boot_attach_live_migrate_and_delete_server_with_secgroups.json <configs/boot_attach_live_migrate_and_delete_server_with_secgroups.json>`, :download:`create-and-delete-image.json <configs/create-and-delete-image.json>` and :download:`keystone.json <configs/keystone.json>` scenarios. 4. Create deployment.json file in WORK_DIR and fill it with OpenStack environment info. It should looks like this: .. code:: json { "admin": { "password": "password", "tenant_name": "tenant", "username": "user" }, "auth_url": "http://1.2.3.4:5000/v2.0", "region_name": "RegionOne", "type": "ExistingCloud", "endpoint_type": "internal", "admin_port": 35357, "https_insecure": true } 5. Create job-params.yaml file in WORK_DIR and fill it with scenarios info. It should looks like this: .. code:: yaml --- concurrency: 5 compute: 196 start_cidr: "1.0.0.0/16" current_path: "/home/rally/rally-scenarios/heat/" floating_ip_amount: 800 floating_net: "admin_floating_net" vlan_amount: 1025 gre_enabled: false http_server_with_glance_images: "1.2.3.4" 6. Perform tests: .. code:: bash ${WORK_DIR:?} DEPLOYMENT_NAME="$(uuidgen)" DEPLOYMENT_CONFIG="${WORK_DIR}/deployment.json" PLUGIN_PATH="${WORK_DIR}/plugins/nova_scale.py" JOB_PARAMS_CONFIG="${WORK_DIR}/job-params.yaml" rally deployment create --filename $(DEPLOYMENT_CONFIG) --name $(DEPLOYMENT_NAME) SCENARIOS="boot_attach_live_migrate_and_delete_server_with_secgroups create-and-delete-image keystone.json" for scenario in SCENARIOS; do rally --plugin-paths ${PLUGINS_PATH} task start --tag ${scenario} --task-args-file ${JOB_PARAMS_CONFIG} ${WORK_DR}/scenarios/${scenario} done task_list="$(rally task list --uuids-only)" rally task report --tasks ${task_list} --out=${WORK_DIR}/rally_report.html As a result of this part we got the following HTML file: :download:`rally_report.html <configs/rally_report.html>` Test results ============ Cinder ------ +---------------+---------+----------+----------+---------+---------+ | Operation | Mean | 90%ile | 50%ile | Max | Min | +===============+=========+==========+==========+=========+=========+ | create_volume | 2.61858 | 2.75346 | 2.59307 | 2.98796 | 2.45277 | +---------------+---------+----------+----------+---------+---------+ | delete_volume | 2.33858 | 2.44943 | 2.3231 | 2.66589 | 2.19949 | +---------------+---------+----------+----------+---------+---------+ Glance ------ +--------------+----------+----------+----------+----------+-----------+ | Operation | Mean | 90%ile | 50%ile | Max | Min | +==============+==========+==========+==========+==========+===========+ | create_image | 44.2035 | 56.2428 | 43.8352 | 74.8263 | 22.3818 | +--------------+----------+----------+----------+----------+-----------+ | delete_image | 1.57917 | 2.04929 | 1.53978 | 3.84559 | 0.717697 | +--------------+----------+----------+----------+----------+-----------+ Keystone -------- +-------------+-----------+----------+-----------+----------+-----------+ | Operation | Mean | 90%ile | 50%ile | Max | Min | +=============+===========+==========+===========+==========+===========+ | keystone | 0.0985963 | 0.134554 | 0.0925241 | 0.718329 | 0.0535679 | +-------------+-----------+----------+-----------+----------+-----------+ Neutron ------- +--------------------------+----------+----------+----------+----------+----------+ | Operation | Mean | 90%ile | 50%ile | Max | Min | +==========================+==========+==========+==========+==========+==========+ | create_20_rules | 4.53496 | 4.88304 | 4.51488 | 5.57663 | 3.87322 | +--------------------------+----------+----------+----------+----------+----------+ | create_2_security_groups | 0.41211 | 0.477026 | 0.400622 | 0.669469 | 0.29145 | +--------------------------+----------+----------+----------+----------+----------+ | delete_2_security_groups | 0.380397 | 0.479877 | 0.370746 | 0.771146 | 0.234389 | +--------------------------+----------+----------+----------+----------+----------+ Nova ---- +----------------------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+ | Operation | Mean | 90%ile | 50%ile | Max | Min | +======================+===========+===========+===========+===========+===========+ | attach_volume | 2.80599 | 2.9852 | 2.78055 | 3.29423 | 2.56341 | +----------------------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+ | boot_server | 11.9892 | 12.9366 | 11.9526 | 14.2652 | 9.48223 | +----------------------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+ | delete_server | 2.53095 | 2.67005 | 2.46706 | 4.81662 | 2.34785 | +----------------------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+ | detach_volume | 2.70046 | 2.86138 | 2.68364 | 3.20055 | 2.46385 | +----------------------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+ | find_host_to_migrate | 0.554378 | 0.682363 | 0.520207 | 0.954408 | 0.418872 | +----------------------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+ | live_migrate | 15.351 | 15.7149 | 15.2205 | 28.6921 | 12.6233 | +----------------------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+-----------+ .. references: .. _Rally installation documentation: https://rally.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install.html
